facts.text: Gujar Singh died after District Judge decision; respondents are his heirs and legal representatives.

anchor.surface_text: Accordingly, he allowed the appeal. Gujar Singh died sometime after the appellate decision, and the present respondents as heirs and legal representatives of Gujar Singh carried a second appeal to the Punjab High Court.

facts.text: High Court held short period of six weeks living together insufficient for association; set aside District Judge, restored trial court.

facts.text: Customary adoption amongst Jats of Ludhiana requires declaration and general treatment as son.

anchor.surface_text: It is clear, however, that so far as the Jats of Ludhiana district are concerned, the formalities necessary for adoption are, firstly, a declaration of adoption and, secondly, general treatment of the appointed heir as a son.

concepts.unlisted_label: Customary Adoption Rules for Jats of Ludhiana District
concepts.unlisted_description: Valid adoption requires (i) declaration of adoption (e.g., before panchayat, distributing gur, or deed) and (ii) general treatment of appointee as son; no special formalities or religious ceremony needed; mere declaration or deed without accompanying treatment insufficient.

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Achhru Ram appearing on behalf of the appellant has contended that the view expressed by the learned District Judge is the correct view. He has referred us to the general statement of the customary rule in the matter of the appointment of an heir in paragraph 35 at p. 50 of Rattigans Digest of Customary Law seventh edition . That paragraph, with Explanation 1, reads as follows A sonless proprietor of land in the central and eastern parts of the Punjab may appoint one of his kinsmen to succeed him as his heir.

concepts.interpretation: General Punjab customary rule cited by appellant but court prefers district-specific Rewaj-i-Am evidence over general statement; notes alternative modes including declaration, deed with treatment, or long course of treatment.

interpretation_anchor.surface_text: y rule in the matter of the appointment of an heir in paragraph 35 at p. 50 of Rattigans Digest of Customary Law  seventh edition . That paragraph, wi

concepts.unlisted_label: Customary Appointment of Heir (Rattigan's Digest Para 35)
concepts.unlisted_description: Sonless proprietor may appoint kinsman as heir by formal declaration before brotherhood, written declaration with consistent treatment, or long course of treatment evidencing intention.

anchor.surface_text: This, in the opinion of the learned District Judge, was sufficient to establish a valid adoption according to the customary rules and no further evidence, of association as father and son between the two was necessary. In this view of the matter, the learned District Judge held that the cancellation of the deed of adoption by Nathu on September 6, 1946, was of no effect, because an adoption once validly made could not be revoked.

concepts.interpretation: Principle invoked by District Judge to ignore cancellation deed, but Supreme Court does not apply as precondition of valid adoption not satisfied.

issues.text: whether Inder Singh, plaintiff in the court of first instance and appellant herein, was validly adopted by one Nathu in accordance with the rules of customary adoption prevalent amongst Jats of the Ludhiana district in the State of Punjab

anchor.surface_text: The only question which falls for decision is whether Inder Singh, plaintiff in the companyrt of first instance and appellant herein, was validly adopted by one Nathu in accordance with the rules of customary adoption prevalent amongst Jats of the Ludhiana district in the State of Punjab.

issues.text: whether under the customary rules of adoption prevalent amongst the Jats of Ludhiana, a second element for a valid adoption, namely, an act of association or a general treatment of the appointed heir as a son is essential

anchor.surface_text: The controversy in the High Court as also before us centered round the question whether under the cus- tomary rules of adoption prevalent amongst the Jats of Ludhiana, a second element for a valid adoption, namely, an act of association or a general treatment of the appointed heir as a son is essential.

issues.text: the rules of customary adoption prevalent amongst the parties required two essential elements (a) an intention to appoint an heir and (b) an act of association between the two as father and son

anchor.surface_text: The learned Judges of the High Court held that the rules of customary adoption prevalent amongst the parties required two essential elements  a  an intention to appoint an heir and  b  an act of association between the two as father and son.

arguments.claim: For Jats of Ludhiana, adoption requires declaration + general treatment as son; mere declaration or deed insufficient without treatment

anchor.surface_text: It is clear, however, that so far as the Jats of Ludhiana district are concerned, the formalities necessary for adoption are, firstly, a declaration of adoption and, secondly, general treatment of the appointed heir as a son. A mere declaration or even the execution of a deed of adoption unaccompanied by precedent or subsequent treatment is insufficient.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Under CPC provisions for second appeals, findings of fact by the first appellate court are binding and not re-examinable.

holdings.text: For Jats of Ludhiana district, formalities necessary for adoption are firstly a declaration of adoption and secondly general treatment of the appointed heir as a son; a mere declaration or execution of a deed of adoption unaccompanied by precedent or subsequent treatment is insufficient.

anchor.surface_text: It is clear, however, that so far as the Jats of Ludhiana district are concerned, the formalities necessary for adoption are, firstly, a declaration of adoption and, secondly, general treatment of the appointed heir as a son.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Derived from authoritative Rewaj-i-Am for Ludhiana district stating declaration and general treatment sufficient, supported by case law; local custom prevails over general Punjab rule in Rattigan's Digest.

holdings.text: The Rewaj-i-Am for Ludhiana district provides unimpeachable evidence of the scope of the customary adoption rule applicable to Jats of that district.

anchor.surface_text: We consider that it is unnecessary in this case to examine the more general question of the exact scope and ambit of the rule in other parts of the Punjab for we have unimpeachable evidence of the scope of the rule in the district of Ludhiana. In the Customary Law of the Ludhiana District rewaj-i-am

holdings.reasoning_summary: Rewaj-i-Am compiled by Settlement Officer is authoritative statement of local custom, conceded by counsel; case law agrees no special formalities needed beyond intention and treatment.

holdings.text: In the circumstances of this case, the declaration before the village Panchayat and execution of the deed of adoption, which was cancelled within a short time, were not a sufficient manifestation of intention to adopt; there was no evidence of treatment as son, only repudiation.

anchor.surface_text: In the case before us, Nathu died three years after the execution of the deed. He left Inder Singh a few weeks after the execution of the deed, cancelled the deed within about five months and instead of treating Inder Singh as his son repudiated any such association with him.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Short cohabitation of weeks insufficient for general treatment; Nathu left, cancelled deed in five months, repudiated association till death three years later; precedents distinguish cases with prompt suit or long treatment.

holdings.text: The High Court was clearly right in its decision that there was no valid adoption according to customary rules amongst Jats of Ludhiana.

anchor.surface_text: A mere declaration or even the execution of a deed of adoption unaccompanied by precedent or subsequent treatment is insufficient. That being the position, the High Court was clearly right in its decision.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Applying two-element customary rule to facts showing lack of association/treatment, affirming High Court's reversal of District Judge.

anchor.surface_text: Gurbachna v. Bujha 1 . In that case it was stated that where the power of customary adoption by a sonless proprietor was number disputed, all that was necessary to companystitute an adoption was the clear expression of an intention on the part of the adoptive father to adopt the boy companycerned as his son and a sufficient manifestation of that intention by the execution and registration of a deed of adoption companypled with a clear declaration in companyrt and subsequent treatment as adopted son. It was pointed out, however, that in a case where soon after the execution of the deed of adoption the reversioners of the adoptive father brought a suit, it was number reason

precedents.cited_proposition: clear expression of intention to adopt manifested by deed of adoption coupled with declaration in court and subsequent treatment as son; no need for subsequent treatment if suit brought soon after deed
precedents.cited_holding: sufficient manifestation by deed + declaration + treatment, but not requiring treatment if challenged soon

precedents.citation: Baj Singh v. Partap Singh 1923 77 I.C. 473

precedents.cited_proposition: appointment valid if made in unequivocal and customary manner; execution of deed coupled with long course of treatment recognised mode

precedents.cited_holding: adoption not established without continuous treatment

precedents.cited_proposition: appointment manifested by declaration or course of treatment evidencing unequivocal intention; essence is clear declaration; involved declaration in court plus subsequent treatment

anchor.surface_text: Kishan Singh v. Taru  4  it was observed that all that was necessary to companystitute an adoption under customary law was the clear expression of intention on the adoptive fathers part to adopt the boy companycerned as his son, and the execution of the deed of adoption companypled with a clear declaration before a registering officer and companytinuous subsequent treatment as adopted son were sufficient manifestation of the intention.

precedents.cited_proposition: clear expression of intention to adopt, manifested by deed coupled with declaration before registering officer and continuous subsequent treatment as son

anchor.surface_text: It is clear, however, that so far as the Jats of Ludhiana district are concerned, the formalities necessary for adoption are, firstly, a declaration of adoption and, secondly, general treatment of the appointed heir as a son.
That being the position, the High Court was clearly right in its decision.
